unnormalised: Okay, here's the generated blog post, focusing on dates and times in the context of news and media reporting, in a narrative tone, around the target length of 10 paragraphs:
normalised: It feels like just yesterday, but it was actually on the fifteenth March two thousand and twenty, when the world truly started to understand the gravity of what was happening. I remember precisely, I was scrolling through T-w-i-t-t-e-r at around ten thirty A-M I-S-T, sipping my morning chai, when the breaking news alerts started flooding my feed. It was about the W-H-O declaring C-O-V-I-D-nineteen a pandemic.

unnormalised: It feels like just yesterday, but it was actually on 15/03/2020, when the world truly started to understand the gravity of what was happening. I remember precisely, I was scrolling through Twitter at around 10:30 AM IST, sipping my morning chai, when the breaking news alerts started flooding my feed. It was about the WHO declaring COVID-19 a pandemic.
normalised: Everything shifted after that. News cycles became a blur of grim statistics and uncertainty. I'd wake up every day, check the headlines at seven A-M, and the numbers would already be drastically different from the night before. Lockdowns were announced, extended, and then re-imposed. Remember the Janta Curfew on twenty second March two thousand and twenty? It felt like a movie, a silent, eerie pause before the storm really hit.

unnormalised: Everything shifted after that. News cycles became a blur of grim statistics and uncertainty. I'd wake up every day, check the headlines at 7:00 AM, and the numbers would already be drastically different from the night before. Lockdowns were announced, extended, and then re-imposed. Remember the Janta Curfew on 22/03/2020? It felt like a movie, a silent, eerie pause before the storm really hit.
normalised: I was working as a junior reporter then, covering local events. Everything was cancelled. The annual Diwali mela scheduled for fourteenth November two thousand and twenty? Gone. The Republic Day parade on twenty sixth January two thousand and twenty one? Virtual only. My beat became tracking the daily C-O-V-I-D-nineteen case count and reporting on the impact on our community.

unnormalised: I was working as a junior reporter then, covering local events. Everything was cancelled. The annual Diwali mela scheduled for 14/11/2020? Gone. The Republic Day parade on 26/01/2021? Virtual only. My beat became tracking the daily COVID-19 case count and reporting on the impact on our community.
normalised: One particularly heart-wrenching story I covered was about a family who lost their father. He passed away on fifth May two thousand and twenty one at approximately six P-M. Because of the restrictions, they couldn't even hold a proper funeral. The grief was palpable, a heavy cloud hanging over everything.

unnormalised: One particularly heart-wrenching story I covered was about a family who lost their father. He passed away on 05/05/2021 at approximately 6:00 PM. Because of the restrictions, they couldn't even hold a proper funeral. The grief was palpable, a heavy cloud hanging over everything.
normalised: The news channels were on twenty four seven, broadcasting updates, expert opinions, and heartbreaking stories. The anxiety was infectious. Every press conference, every government announcement, was dissected and analyzed. I recall the address by the Prime Minister on the evening of twelfth May two thousand and twenty; it felt like the whole nation held its breath together, waiting for answers, for hope.

unnormalised: The news channels were on 24/7, broadcasting updates, expert opinions, and heartbreaking stories. The anxiety was infectious. Every press conference, every government announcement, was dissected and analyzed. I recall the address by the Prime Minister on the evening of 12/05/2020; it felt like the whole nation held its breath together, waiting for answers, for hope.
normalised: As time went on, the vaccine rollout brought a glimmer of optimism. The initial vaccination drives started on sixteenth January two thousand and twenty one. News of successful trials and increasing vaccination rates became a much-needed balm for our weary souls. Finally some good news.

unnormalised: As time went on, the vaccine rollout brought a glimmer of optimism. The initial vaccination drives started on 16/01/2021. News of successful trials and increasing vaccination rates became a much-needed balm for our weary souls. Finally some good news.
normalised: The impact of the pandemic on the news industry was profound. The shift to digital was accelerated, the demand for accurate and timely information was higher than ever. Fact-checking became crucial, battling the spread of misinformation and fake news that seemed to multiply exponentially.

unnormalised: The impact of the pandemic on the news industry was profound. The shift to digital was accelerated, the demand for accurate and timely information was higher than ever. Fact-checking became crucial, battling the spread of misinformation and fake news that seemed to multiply exponentially.
normalised: Now, as I look back at the news archives from that period, those dates and times trigger a rush of memories. The fear, the uncertainty, the resilience, the moments of collective grief and collective hope. It was a period that redefined our world and changed the way we consume and process information.

normalised: Life slowly limped back to normalcy in early two thousand and twenty two, but the scars remained. It has been over two years since the formal announcement of the end of the pandemic at the global stage. The scheduled review is on thirty first December two thousand and twenty four.

unnormalised: Life slowly limped back to normalcy in early 2022, but the scars remained. It has been over two years since the formal announcement of the end of the pandemic at the global stage. The scheduled review is on 31/12/2024.
normalised: The experience taught me the importance of responsible journalism, the need for empathy, and the power of community in the face of adversity. It's a chapter in history that I will never forget, a constant reminder of the fragility of life and the importance of staying informed. And a constant reminder of how dates and times marked the milestones of our collective experience.
